case_title: Mir Nabi Bakhsh Zehri and 36 Others vs Government of Baluchistan Through Chief Secretary and 5 Others
reference_no_or_id: Writ Petitions Nos. 26, 27, 34 to 42, 54, 55, 60, 64, 65 and 81 of 1975
respondant: Government of Baluchistan Through Chief Secretary
complaint_summary: Petitioners challenged the Land Reforms (Baluchistan Pat Feeder Canal) Regulation No. 117, alleging it was discriminatory and violated constitutional rights.
investigation_summary: Petitioners filed applications under Regulation No. 117 for land retention. Federal Land Commission intervened, setting aside certain orders and delaying confirmation proceedings.
judgment_summary: The court dismissed the petitions, holding that Regulation No. 117 was immune from constitutional challenges due to its inclusion in the First Schedule of the Constitution. Amendments and procedural delays did not render the Regulation unconstitutional.
legal_arguments: Regulation No. 117 alleged to violate Article 4 of the Constitution.
Petitioners argued amendments made the Regulation justiciable.
Defense cited constitutional immunity under Article 8 and First Schedule.
statutes: Land Reforms (Baluchistan Pat Feeder Canal) Regulation No. 117
citations: Mehreen Zebun Nisa v. Land Commissioner, Multan and others (P L D 1975 S C 397)

legal_terms.Sanad: An authentic document granting rights or interests in land.

words_and_phrases.Indigent: A person lacking sufficient means to support themselves.

summary_vector_notes: The case involved 17 petitions challenging the Land Reforms (Baluchistan Pat Feeder Canal) Regulation No. 117, alleging discrimination and constitutional violations. The court upheld the Regulation's immunity under Article 8 and dismissed the petitions, citing procedural assurances from the Federal Land Commission.
